text:
JESSICA LUTZGER: Hi, everyone. My name is Jessica Lutzger. I'm an HBS alum, and I also
work in the admissions office,

and I'm so happy to
have you all here today. We have three women who
are in their second year

at HBS here with us. And we have a lot of questions. Thank you so much for
being so thoughtful

and for sending in
all those questions, and we're going to try to
get to everything that you asked in the next hour
that we have together.

Before we do that,
I want to give you a brief overview of HBS. We have a two-year, full-time
general management MBA program.

So we did get a lot of
questions about online learning and part-time programs. Those are not part
of what we're going

to be talking about today. The students are going
to talk a little bit more about the curriculum
and how that runs.

But a couple of things you're
going to hear about today are the case method. That's a really
important part of the way

we learn here at HBS. You're going to
hear some acronyms like required curriculum,
which is the first year.

Everyone does the same
thing in the first year. And then EC which is
Elective Curriculum, which

is the second year. We have a residential campus
here in Boston, and about 65%

of our students live on campus,
and they'll talk a little bit about what they do when
they're in the classroom and when they're out
of the classroom.

We have 930 students in each
class, but in the first year, those students are divided
into groups of 93 which

form a section, and we'll talk
a little bit more about that. HBS has a really
robust alumni network

with 83,000 alums in
170 different countries, and those are alums
of our MBA programs

as well as our
executive education programs which are on campus. And 15,000 of those are women.

So that's a pretty
amazing group of women who offer support to our students.

We'll talk a little bit
about the field program which is part of our curriculum. And then we'll
touch on how people

have thought about
their job searches and what they're
doing after school. So with that, I
want to get started

and we're going to
meet the students.

OK, great. So thank you for coming today. And can you all
introduce yourself.
Leila, I'll ask you to start. LAYLA: Sure. Hi, everyone. Thanks for joining. My name is Leila.

I am from New Jersey. I went to Howard
University for undergrad

and prior to HBS I worked in a
couple of different industries,

first in the industrial space so
I worked in general management for an industrial
distribution company.

I then transitioned
to financial services and worked for Goldman Sachs in
human capital for three years.

So I focused on succession
planning and diversity and inclusion work there. In my second year at HBS, along
with these two lovely ladies,

I'm involved with a lot of
really exciting things here, so I'm sure we'll get to
talk about that as well.

JESSICA LUTZGER: Great. REBECCA DAUSCHA: Hi, my
name is Rebecca Dauscha. I am Brazilian. I'm from Sao Paulo. I said economics University
of Sao Paulo, and prior to HBS

I worked three years
as a consultant at the German company
called Rowland Berger, and then I worked two years
as an internal consultant

at Bayer, the
pharmaceutical industry. And before coming, I had a brief
experience as a brand manager

in Brazil managing
the Coppertone brand. KALLE: All right. Hi, my name is
Kalle [? Clorin. ?]

I'm from Vancouver, Canada. Before HBS I worked
for General Electric primarily in sub-Saharan Africa.

I worked on major
infrastructure projects and then I got to dabble in
some global health work as well.

And I'm excited to be here
with these ladies today. JESSICA LUTZGER: Great. Thank you.

So let's think about
your path to the MBA. So Leila how did when you
are ready to apply and leave

the role you were in
prior to business school? LAYLA: Yeah, so as I mentioned
right before business school,

I was working in a human
capital role and I loved my job. I loved my team.

It was a really
enjoyable experience. But I think the
moment for me where I knew that I was
ready I was actually

up for my next promotion
and I didn't really want it.

And that was kind
of a sign to me that I needed a different
set of experiences, whether it was either
at another company

or in a graduate program. Ultimately decided that
going to grad school was the right fit for me because
I was really in this place

where I wanted to explore. And I wasn't exactly sure what
I wanted out of my next role,

but I knew it wasn't
at the company that I was currently working
at and in the same function

as well. So despite the
fact that I really enjoyed what I was
doing, I recognized

that I didn't really
have the drive to seek the next sort
of level at my job

or if I didn't see myself
really like represented in the folks that were
already in those positions,

then it was probably time for
me to consider something else. JESSICA LUTZGER: Did anyone
have anything different

or any other thoughts as you
thought about when to apply? REBECCA DAUSCHA: Yeah, I think
in my case, I was at Bayer

and I was starting
managing some people, but I never had
the time to really reflect about my leadership
style and [? what ?]

my strengths and
weaknesses as a leader. So I wanted to have like
a time as soon as possible my career to reflect
on that before I

start leading bigger groups. JESSICA LUTZGER: What made
you choose HBS Rebecca?

REBECCA DAUSCHA: Yeah, I think
the case method was something that I decided to
pursue because it's very out of my comfort zone.

So as not native English
speakers speaking in front of 90 people
a little bit scary, but I also wanted to choose MBA
to do like my personal growth.

So the case method
was something that was really interesting for me. So I came to HBS
to visit the class,

and I was impressed by the
debates, the discussions, and how can you really
absorb the learning when

you're doing a case method. So this was a reason number one. And the second reason was
the section experience

because I came to the
US, and I didn't just want to make a network,
I wanted to make friends. And I think if you have
a group of 90 people

that you really live with
them like every single day, you can really make
true connections.

So I was very excited
to have a section. And I can confirm it
was very, very nice. I really enjoy the experience.

JESSICA LUTZGER: That's great. And any fears or reservations
about getting an MBA?

KALLE: Yeah, I think for a
lot of us it's a bit daunting. You hear a lot about
Harvard Business School,

especially throughout
the application process. You know you take the GMAT. It can sometimes be a
daunting experience.

I think you expect the academics
to be extremely challenging. And although they
are not easy, I

think that the
admissions committee does an extremely good
job of making sure that they've selected you for
your particular skill set.

And you have to figure out what
that is throughout the year, but you figure out that you
do have something very unique

to add to the case discussions. So I think you do
find your place and you realize you
have a valuable skill,

and you can also
learn from your peers. And then in addition
to that, if you don't come from necessarily a
quant background or a business

background, there's a lot
of preparation activity you can do throughout the
summer that they provide you. So there's a bunch of
different core courses.

I recommend them. But you really are
set up for success. And there's access
to different tutors.

The professors are very
open to speaking with you, so the academics are
definitely manageable.

JESSICA LUTZGER: That's
great and Rebecca, can you talk a little bit about
financing the MBA because I know that's a big fear
for a lot of people

who are on the other
side of the camera. REBECCA DAUSCHA: Yeah,
so especially coming from another country where
the currency is undervalued,

financing my MBA
was one of my things I was worried about
because I didn't have a company sponsoring me. But I was very impressed
by the HBS financial aid

because it's not
merit-based, it's need-based. So it is very customized
to your needs. So it helped me a lot,
making sure I could come here

with peace of mind, knowing
that I could finance my MBA, enjoy the experience, and
then think about it like

and spread the financing
across the years was also something that
helps me a lot here.

JESSICA LUTZGER:
That makes sense. Leila, can you talk a little
bit about the curriculum at HBS.

I sort of touched on it briefly,
but if you could sort of walk through how HBS is
structured that would be great.

LAYLA: Yeah, so in the first
year, as we already mentioned,

everybody does the same thing. And so one of the first
things that happened is that you are
assigned your section.

And so your section is comprised
of about 90 or 93 or so people

from all different
walks of life, all over the world, all
different backgrounds, and so that becomes your family,
essentially, for the year.

All of your classes take
place in the same classroom, and you'll have I think five in
the fall and then another five

classes in the spring. The structure of the actual
classroom experience,

as we've mentioned,
is the case method. And so a good way to
understand the case method

is you're essentially
studying a business problem from the perspective
of the person

directly dealing
with that issue. It could be the CEO. It could be the
head of marketing. It could be the CFO.

And the courses are
designed for you to put yourselves in
that person's shoes

and come prepared
to class every day with a perspective on how
you think that person should

solve that particular problem. In terms of materials,
the case method

is all based on case
studies, and so at the start of the year, you'll
receive all of or most

of your cases for the entire
year or the entire semester rather.

And so your
preparation for class is largely going to be based
on those individual case

studies for each class. Every class is usually
on a different company,

a different problem,
a new protagonist. One of the cool things about
the case method here at HBS

is a lot of the case
protagonists actually come visit the classroom. And so you'll spend the first
half of the class talking

about your different
perspectives on the issue and then spend the
latter half hearing from the actual person who
made the decision themselves,

which is pretty cool. Another really interesting
part of the case method,

which you sort of alluded to
in terms of public speaking skills, is it really
forces you to engage

with everyone else in the room. And there might be times where
people agree with your points

and people don't agree. And that's part of
the education process is recognizing that there are
multiple different approaches

for solving business
problems, and hearing that sort of intellectual
diversity in the classroom

is really important. So each day you'll leave
that particular class or case

with several
different approaches, several different
responses, perspectives,

on that particular issue. And I think that's
really valuable, versus you kind of keeping
your head down and coming up

with your approach alone
or learning something from a textbook.

Like you're learning
with your professor you're learning with
your peers and it's a really collective and
enjoyable experience.

JESSICA LUTZGER:
Actually, Rebecca, can you talk a little
bit about FIELD and that part of the experience?

REBECCA DAUSCHA: Yeah,
the FIELD foundation's it's the course that we have
in the first semester that helps us creating this
interpersonal skills.

And we also have-- you mean the F [INAUDIBLE],,
the trip, or more? JESSICA LUTZGER: Yep. REBECCA DAUSCHA:
Yeah so it's a very--

for me it was one of
the best parts of HBS. So it's you have a group and
you work in a project, design

thinking project, for
an external organization in another country. So in my case, I
went to South Korea

and I spent 10 days
there with my group. And first, like design thinking
process is very interesting.

So I really learned how to use
it and apply it in real life. So I think the learning
was like real for me

because I not only
learned at classroom, but I really applied [? it. ?] And going to another
country experiencing another culture or
something very special.

And having also the
support from HBS to have also contact with
students in Korea. We also had contacts
with professors there,

so it was very enriching for me. And also making friends
from other sections was very nice too.

JESSICA LUTZGER: Kalle,
where did you go for FIELD? KALLE: I also went
to South Korea. JESSICA LUTZGER:
Oh, that's funny. Yeah.

Where did you go? LAYLA: I went to Tanzania,
so my FGI section was in Dar Es Salaam.

And it was really cool
to be in an emerging market for that experience.

And I would echo a lot
of what you've said. I'm still very close
with the friends I made. I'm actually having
dinner with them tonight--

JESSICA LUTZGER: Nice. LAYLA: --which is really cool. But our client was
actually based in Zanzibar,

and so much of the
10 days we spent there was traveling
back and forth

via boat to get to the customers
and clients in Zanzibar.

JESSICA LUTZGER:
What was the project? LAYLA: So the project
was we were basically helping a salt company.

And so in Zanzibar,
one of the issues that our founder that
we were working with

was trying to solve was the lack
of iodized salt in local dukas

or markets in Zanzibar. And so the lack of iodized
salt presented a lot of different health
issues in the community

in terms of different
conditions that result from iodine deficiencies. And so what we were trying
to do was introduce a product

into the market that
wouldn't necessarily change the habits of consumers there. And so part of our
design thinking process

was a lot of customer interviews
and learning about what their normal habits were like.

And what that involved is us
literally going to the markets and walking side by side with
local people saying like,

hey, why did you purchase this
kind of salt versus that kind and really understanding what
people's perceptions were

of local goods
versus imported goods and people's reactions
to different brands

or health advisory statements
or things like that. And so ultimately what we
did is come up with a brand

name, a go-to-market
strategy, and really just a bunch of different
recommendations for our founder

in terms of how to engage
with the community there, based on what we learn from
the people that we spoke to.

And it was really
incredible experience. I don't think I
ever would have gone

to a place like that on
my own, which it changes

your perspective I think a lot,
and has made me more interested in emerging markets in
direct-to-consumer businesses

and learning a little bit more
about different health-related issues that impact business
in those parts of the world as

well. JESSICA LUTZGER: That's great. Kalle, really quickly,
can you tell us what second year
courses you're taking?

KALLE: Yeah, for sure. So I'm in one course
that's cross registered, which is an interesting
thing you can do at HBS.

And it's with kind of like the
public health, the law school, and all the other schools. And essentially we're
creating a business plan

to tackle a major issue that
we've kind of all come together to select. So we're looking at kind of
malaria in sub-Saharan Africa.

And then to complement
that I'm also taking a bunch of different
entrepreneurship courses here at HBS.

I'm taking Founder's Journey. It's really interesting where
you have-- you kind of look through the lens of a
bunch of different founders

and they come in
class and kind of talk about some of the emotional
aspects of being a founder and how tough it can be.

And I'm sure some
people on this call are founders, so
congrats to you. And then I'm also taking
public entrepreneurship at HBS.

And this is looking
at in terms of how do people disrupt
the public sector through different
entrepreneurial initiatives,

whether that be from
the private sector or from the public sector. And I'm also taking
a few other courses

that I don't know if you want
me to go through all my classes. JESSICA LUTZGER: Just to
give people a taste of some of the things that you can--

KALLE: Yeah, so I
mean I've highly indexed on
entrepreneurial courses because I'm quite
interested in this.

But you can also take obviously
a variety of different finance courses. Some of the folks have
found various courses

in private equity extremely
useful for what they're going to be doing post career. I've kind of
focused more on some of these qualitative
courses this semester.

JESSICA LUTZGER:
Yeah, that's OK. So Rebecca you
talked a little bit about the case method
and the opportunity

to speak in the classroom,
and that was sort of a reason why you chose HBS. How have you
experienced it and do

you feel do you feel
good about your choice to go to a school that
really uses a case method

and do you feel
like being a woman has impacted how you
feel in the classroom? That question comes up a lot.

REBECCA DAUSCHA: Yeah. No, I'm very happy with
the decision I really enjoyed the case method. But I must say in the
beginning is not easy because you have to adapt
speaking to a big public.

Also for me I have a hard
time saying something when I'm not 100% sure. And here you have to learn how
to speak when you're like 75%

sure because the cases
they don't give you all the data you need. They're not going to
give you all the context. So for me the beginning was
very hard to raise my hand

because I wanted to have
a very clear point of view before doing that. But I think the women community
in my section was very strong.

So they gave me
a lot of support. So for example, my
seatmate, she was amazing and my first comment she was
like reinforcing me and saying

like this was a great comment. I really learned
with what you said, and that was like giving
me more confidence to start risking more and start
like talking more at class.

And I also had a comment buddy. It was another
woman in my section. So after every class
we got together

and then we gave
feedback to each other about her participation. So I think like the our
women in the section

are very like close together
and collaborative to make sure everyone is
participating and that we have equal participation
between men and women

and that everyone feel
included to contribute. Because this is the
beauty of the case method. If you stay quiet and you don't
bring your own point of view

this is not nice. We want to hear everyone's
voices and experiences. It can be from
different industries

or different countries. This is what makes it, I think,
a very nice way of learning. JESSICA LUTZGER: That's great.

Kalle, have you found any
mentors at HBS or anyone who you've gotten great advice
from or particularly connected

with? KALLE: Yeah, so one of the
things I'm involved in at HBS is the Health Care Club. And I didn't come from a
health care background,

but was really interested
in switching into this. So I participated in
something called our doctor shadowing program
or an opportunity

to kind of leverage all
the amazing health care institutions around Boston,
so Mass General, Brigham,

and Women's Hospital,
and actually connect with a bunch of
physicians most of whom were Harvard professors at
some point in their career

or currently, and shadow them
around on their day to day, and in the emergency
rooms and sometimes

in their global health
incubator, things like that. So I really got a
great perspective of what it means to do
health care with kind of more

from the medical perspective. And they kind of did allow
me to better understand with an MBA skill set where
we could best contribute.

So that was really helpful
[? for ?] my career decision. JESSICA LUTZGER:
Rebecca or Layla, any professors that you've had
that particularly stand out
to you? LAYLA: Oh, for sure. My, our lead.

We were in the-- Kalle and I were in
the same section. But my lead professor from
last year Joshua Margolis

was fantastic. Just a career academic,
very, very knowledgeable

about all of the different
topics that we were discussing, and really had a great way of
mastering the classroom, such

that we were almost trained
to speak to each other. I think that's one of the
unique transitions for coming

into the case
method is you think that based on how you
were socialized in school

is if there's a question
asked you respond directly to the professor
or to the teacher. And in this
environment it's really

supposed to be
training you to have a conversation with each other. But I say that to say he
was very good at managing

those dynamics and was also
very open to connecting with all of us outside
of the classroom as well.

He's currently my advisor
for an independent project that I'm working on and
has also given a lot

of career advice to me as well. So it's just one example. I think the faculty here are
super dedicated and very, very

open to building
relationships with students and helping us, not just in
terms of our academic pursuits,

but professionally as well. KALLE: One thing just to
add to that was really neat is this professor came in
because our original professor

was Larry Culp who's now
the CEO of General Electric. And he came into
class and said he's sorry he can't teach us
any longer because he

has to go be the CEO of GE,
so it was pretty interesting. I think these things happen
at HBS once in a while.

But he stayed very
connected to our class and then several of
our section mates ended up actually working
for GE this summer.

JESSICA LUTZGER: That's great. I didn't add-- when
we were talking about the courses and
the academic side,

we didn't really talk
about independent studies. Can you just give an example
of your independent study and maybe tell a little
bit about what that is?

LAYLA: Sure. So independent
projects are things that you can do in the EC year,
your second year here at HBS.

And so what that means is you
would essentially put together a proposal to work on a
project in place of a class.

It can either count
for like a full class for the entire semester
or half of a class for like a quarter
of the time if that's

more appropriate for
what you're studying. In my case, I am
actually working on an independent project that
is sort of company-sponsored.

So there are a few different
ways that IPs are set up. One is you can come up
with the idea yourself.

Another is a faculty
member could ask a student to work with them on something,
for example, writing a case.

And the third is
companies often come to HBS and ask to work with
students on specific projects

or deliverables for
their organization. So right now I'm working with
the CEO of an executive search

firm on a study on women
chief executives in the US.

And so what we're looking
at is their trajectories, essentially, to identify common
themes that have enabled them

to be successful on that path. So for example,
looking at questions like what was the composition
of the board at the time

of their appointment
and asking questions around are there
any implications

for the representation
of more women on boards at the time of the appointment
in the CEO succession process,

looking at whether or not they
were an internal or external candidate and
getting a little bit into the details on
different obstacles

that they've might
have experienced. So I'm really enjoying it. I'm learning a lot. And part of the
experience also allows

me to kind of talk to some of
these women and learn from them myself, so it's been really fun.

And there are multiple
other ways to do IPs. Some people, some
of my peers are

working on business
plans for startups that they've always been
interested in pursuing and are using their IP
credits to pursue that.

So it's really
sort of up to you. JESSICA LUTZGER: How
did you get connected with the woman from the
executive search company?

LAYLA: Yeah, so in
one of the areas where we like--
there's something

called the EC toolkit
where we select our classes for the upcoming year.

This is something that you do
at the end of your first year. There's a section on
independent projects,

and the companies
that were interested, that have submitted
proposals to the school,

will have those opportunities
posted in that place. And so it's sort of up to you
as a student to reach out,

and that's what I did. I reached out and said, hey, are
you still looking for a student to work with? I think your proposal
is interesting.

Let's set up time to
talk for 30 minutes and see if it's the right fit. And it ended up being
right, and so that's

kind of how we
progress from there. JESSICA LUTZGER: That's great.

Well, this next
question was for you. What surprised you about HBS?

LAYLA: I guess what
surprised me is how deep the
connections would be

with just the
people you meet here and your section mates as well.

So one example of that is we
have a tradition here at HBS called my takes.

And so what that means is
they're sort of little mini Ted Talks that you can do about
different life experiences

that you've had. And so after hearing a number
of those different stories

in my section, I was really
inspired to share my own and ended up building
really strong relationships

with the people that decided
to come and hear my story. I never expected to share that
part of myself with my peers

here at HBS, but I'm
super glad that I did. And I think it's one of
the ways in which we create

a culture where people
feel like they can truly be authentic here and share
multiple different parts

of their identity. And that was something
really special to be part of. JESSICA LUTZGER: Did
anything surprise

either of the two of you? REBECCA DAUSCHA: Yeah,
I agree completely. I just want to--
[? and ?] like for me what surprised me
was the how easy

is to connect with the faculty. I think you mentioned
this a little bit more. But like for me, I
just like sent emails.

The next day I had
the response having like a day to meet the
professors, so this was very helpful for me in
my career search

and also to talk
about my career goals. So this was something
very impressive, and I'm really taking
advantage of that.

KALLE: Yeah I think also just
the amount of opportunities. I think every hour
you're choosing in a good way between
two or three things

to do from the moment you wake
up till you go to bed probably later than you anticipated. So it's an exciting
chance and you really

want to come in with
a set of priorities because there's just so many
interesting opportunities that come up.

JESSICA LUTZGER: Thinking
about those opportunities and spending time
outside of the classroom,

how do you each spend your
time outside of classroom? Like what are the clubs
that you're involved with

or the things that are
really important to you? And Layla, I'll start with you. LAYLA: OK.

Last year I got involved in
a number of things outside of the classroom, but the
biggest commitments I think

were one section leadership. So we hold elections
in the section

for different positions. I was the admissions
rep for my section so I worked directly with
the admissions office

on a number of different
things, including class visits, webinars
like this, different coffee
chats for prospective students. I really enjoyed that. I'm obviously still involved. JESSICA LUTZGER: [INAUDIBLE].

LAYLA: Another club that I
was involved with last year and still am as the
African-American Student Union,

and so I was involved
with the annual conference that we host in the spring.

And one of the things that
I did for the conference was organized on a panel
on business and politics.

So there have been a
number of different alumni that have gone into careers in
government and public service.

And so we sort of wanted a
place to feature their stories, especially in light
of a number of

different political
conversations that were happening now. So getting involved with
different conferences

is actually another
great way to pursue your different
recruiting pursuits,

because in organizing
those panels you'll often get connected
with different people in the industry that you might
be interested in, and just kind

of another way outside
of the classroom to continue your
professional interests

while you're also working
with a club on campus. But those are just two examples.

I don't know if you
guys have others. REBECCA DAUSCHA:
Yeah, so last year was the woman representative
for my section.

So my job was first
mediating some conversation about gender equality. So we talked a lot
about when we have

cases talking about gender. After that I was like
mediating some conversations and discussions.

I'm still part of the
Women's Student Association. So now I'm the vise
president of careers, so I spend my time
organizing events

to help promoting company
events to connect with women. I'm also organizing a
public speaking workshop

to help all men and women to
have a better public speaking. I was also part of the marketing
club helping the conference.

And here at HBS, I'm
also taking the time to take care of my
health so I'm trying to regulate exercise and
sleep a little bit more.

Sometimes it's hard,
but I still try to have a healthier life then
I think I used to have at work.

I think it's a
moment in your life you can try to put
yourself in your priority and think a little bit more
about what you're doing.

KALLE: Yeah, and I
think in addition to some of the organized
groups, I, on the side I coach

Crossfit. I'm like you try
to keep my health, and this is a fun way to kind
of engage with my section mates and kind of keep a
community of folks

from all different sections. Because I think
sometimes you really want to take these
extracurricular opportunities

to meet people outside
of your section as well. And then I work a
lot with CAMTech which is Mass General's
as global health incubator

through the global
health special interest group in the Health Care Club. A lot of words in that.

But ultimately, we
work on a variety of different
hackathons in the area, so around the opioid
epidemic, gun violence,

and some kind of more
broader global health issues and try to help a bunch
of different groups that are having medical
backgrounds, engineering

backgrounds, think of
things from a business lens and really put that into kind
of a business plan perspective. It's been really interesting
getting engaged in the Boston

community that way. JESSICA LUTZGER: Rebecca,

REBECCA DAUSCHA: Yeah,

It's a club that's for free. They [? don't need ?]
to pay fees. Everyone is part-- all the
women are part of that. And we working a lot
of different fronts.

So we work as I said in my
case, I work with career so how it can help women

We also have people working
to improve women participation in cases, so make sure
we have a good balance

between male and
female protagonists. We also tried to create a
good community on campus,

make sure everyone

activities going on and you can decide to be

People that are
part of the board they have more
active participation. And I joined the
board because I think

it's very important to
talk about this topic and also to make friendships. Inside the board is like a
smaller group inside the WSA,

and we meet regularly. We have very nice conversations. So I joined also to
create this network

and have more impact
on campus too. JESSICA LUTZGER: That's great. And Layla had mentioned
the conferences,

and the WSA has one of
the biggest conferences and everyone is welcome to come. It's don't have to be a student
for any of the conferences

that we have, whether

it's a great way to come
see HBS and experience and actually learn something,

So Kalle, you talked about how
many opportunities there are. Can You just describe what a
typical day looks like maybe

for a student in
their first year, and then you can compare it to
a student in their second year. KALLE: Yeah, for sure.

So I think the one unique aspect
that Layla's kind of already touched on is the section. So your life revolves around
your section in a great way

during your first year. So typically you wake
up and some people try to squeeze in
a workout before,

but then you have
discussion group. And this is a great way,
as I kind of mentioned before about some of the
academic reservations you might

have, is you have an opportunity
to speak about the cases you prepared the night before with
a group of people who aren't

in your section, and they
all have very different backgrounds, and you can kind
of test out some of your ideas and make sure that
you're on the same page.

So you have more confidence
when you speak in class. So that's what you do bright
and early in the morning.

And then you end up
in class at 9:00. And then you have two to three
classes a day with lunch.

And normally all of
your lunches will be booked with friends
and section mates to get to know one another.

And then after that, it is
so dependent on the day, but often you'll have different
opportunities for career events

or very cool speakers
come to campus. A lot of the protagonists that
might have come for a case stay after to have
different discussions

or host different presentations. And then there are a ton of
different extracurricular activities, social activities,
so your section will probably

have some sort of themed event,
so get your Halloween costumes all in one box.

But then if you have a
partner, they're very included. So typically, if you want to
spend time with your partner,

it's not going to be a decision
whether or not to go home and spend time with them. But they're very much
included in the section

and any activities going on. JESSICA LUTZGER:
That makes sense. Layla, did you
have any challenges

being a student at HBS and
how did you overcome them? LAYLA: Yes. So I think we've talked
a little bit about people

who might feel anxious
about coming here if you don't necessarily have

and I certainly did not. Being here at HBS was my
first time in a finance class,

in an accounting class. And I think at the start of

very nervous about how to
handle the academic rigor of the program
and relied heavily

on student academic
services, the tutoring that we have access
to, which is amazing.

It's totally free and you can
use as much of it as you want,

and I definitely did. And so I think once I realized
how many resources there

were here that were
available it was, obviously, made the process
a lot easier to manage

and a lot less stressful
knowing that there were multiple different
outlets for support.

And not just academically,
but also the mental health resources here at
HBS are phenomenal.

And so I know a number
of different people who have taken
advantage of those. I myself have taken
advantage of that

and have encouraged
a lot of other people to seek those resources as well.

HBS really emphasizes

because it can become very
overwhelming at times, depending on what
you're pursuing.

But I think a combination of
finding the right resources on campus, definitely
relying on friends

and your section for
support is a big part of navigating different
anxieties that you might have,

whether they be academic
or social or otherwise. So that was kind of the
challenge I experienced and I

think, obviously, made
it out OK and leveraged the resources that I needed to.

And I think it's a
testament to the fact that you really can come
here with any background and be successful.

Layla, did you use
the alumni network as you went about your

I spent a lot of time
on the phone last year

and had a lot of in-person

is a really great way

to kind of explore different
industries or career opportunities that
you're considering.

And one of the reasons why
that was important to me is because sometimes
it's helpful to get

a perspective of someone
who's been in that role or in that industry for
a longer period of time

versus your section mates who
may have only worked there at a certain level
or other peers

you meet that have kind of
like limited experience. It's still helpful to see what
the most near-term trajectory

might look like in
that job, but it's also helpful to hear from alums
who have been in their roles

for a while that have navigated
different challenges, that have sort of taken
more of a winding path.

And then in terms of getting
connected to those people, there are a number
of different ways. I know Jessica introduced me
to a couple of folks herself,

and I also got
connected to alumni that some of my section
mates had relationships with

or that I met through different
events that happened on campus. A lot of the people who come
back from different companies

to recruit on campus are
actually alumni themselves. And so getting connected
with those people is often a good way of
using an introduction

to get another introduction. And in every
conversation that I had when I was trying to figure
out what I wanted to pursue.

I would always ask like,
well, who else would you recommend me speaking with. And usually that person was
also an alum who would--

and it kind of like
branches out from there. So if you really want to like

for your career search, they
can be super, super helpful. And they really--
they're invested.

They understand what
this experience is like, and they have every

incredible to build

in and just taking ownership of customizing

Yeah, here at HBS

we're very encouraged to

So I would recommend using the
essay and all the submission process to stop and
reflect about yourself

and start really very similar
to thinking what you want. And is like a very
special moment for you.

And also in the

I left the interview.

and I just wrote it just after the interview. And I reread it and it
was like so interesting

how deep I was. And I was kind of afraid

learned how is important
to share and reflect. LAYLA: Yeah, the

in terms of how you're building

to be here for a reason. And so it's important to

to know that part of you. So being vulnerable,
being authentic throughout the process
and while you're here

is what I would say. JESSICA LUTZGER: Those are
